coredata.dc:description: Recently, much work has been devoted to designing catalysts with high porosity and efficient active sites. Although very promising results are achieved using Co/Fe–N–C catalysts based on rotating disk electrode (RDE) tests, actual fuel cell performance is below expectations, probably due to insufficient understanding of the catalyst layer (CL). Therefore, catalyst design should be considered holistically by taking into account CL performance, not only intrinsic activity. Here, Co/Fe–N–C with highly dispersed CoFe nanoalloy in the carbon network is obtained by careful design of Co/Fe-ZIF precursor, resulting in a high oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) site density with good stability. Concerning RDE test in the kinetic region and single cell test (SCT) with complex influence factors, the half-cell test (HCT) is introduced to more accurately evaluate the quality of the Co/Fe–CL. Multi-scale measurements (RDE, HCT and SCT) in different current density ranges allows targeting the key CL influence factors for fuel cell performance.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A Co/Fe–N–C catalyst layer (CL) with highly dispersed CoFe nanoalloy is obtained by careful design of a Co/Fe-ZIF precursor, resulting in a high oxygen reduction reaction site density with good stability in both 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M HClO4. A multi-scale study of different current density ranges (RDE, HCT, and SCT) indicates the CL performance is dominated by comprehensive properties, which include gas diffusion, ion conductivity, and catalyst activity.

Recently, much work has been devoted to designing catalysts with high porosity and efficient active sites. Although very promising results are achieved using Co/Fe–N–C catalysts based on rotating disk electrode (RDE) tests, actual fuel cell performance is below expectations, probably due to insufficient understanding of the catalyst layer (CL). Therefore, catalyst design should be considered holistically by taking into account CL performance, not only intrinsic activity. Here, Co/Fe–N–C with highly dispersed CoFe nanoalloy in the carbon network is obtained by careful design of Co/Fe-ZIF precursor, resulting in a high oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) site density with good stability. Concerning RDE test in the kinetic region and single cell test (SCT) with complex influence factors, the half-cell test (HCT) is introduced to more accurately evaluate the quality of the Co/Fe–CL. Multi-scale measurements (RDE, HCT and SCT) in different current density ranges allows targeting the key CL influence factors for fuel cell performance.

ce:section.ce:para: The high cost, relatively low-performance and instability of the cathode catalyst layer has become a bottleneck in fuel cell applications, thus attracting research efforts to overcome these challenges. To reduce Pt consumption or completely remove Pt, platinum group metal (PGM)-free catalysts have been prepared [1,2]. For instance, catalysts made of Fe, Co, Mn, with similar or superior oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity compared to commercial Pt/C, have been reported based on rotating disk electrode (RDE) studies [3–5]. In fuel cell tests, however only a few PGM-free catalysts achieve the performance and stability that would be expected from RDE analysis [6,7]. This is in part likely due to the substantial influence of the catalyst layer (CL) microstructure (i.e. poor mass transfer properties).

Current efforts are devoted to the design of catalysts by reducing metal particle sizes to the atomic-scale and increasing interface area and catalytic activity. An added benefit of working at the atomic-scale is that the surface energy and electronic environment of metal elements can be changed radically [8]. Several design strategies have led to catalysts with atomically dispersed single metal atoms, which include defect engineering [9], coordination [10] and spatial confinement [11]. Zeolite imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) are a class of porous materials which are abundant in nitrogen and can be utilized as precursors for fabricating single atom catalysts, with the aim of increasing the intrinsic ORR activity [12]. The inherent porous structures of ZIF-8 (Zn-based ZIF) constructed with pores (d p = 3.4 Å) and cages (d c = 11.6 Å) [13] provide an alternative structure to isolate and encapsulate metal ions, which are converted to M-Nx species after pyrolysis and serve as the active centers for ORR. The coordination characteristics of metal elements surrounded by N species within ZIF can also strengthen the dispersed active center, hopefully leading to robust highly reactive ORR catalysts.

Based on extensive research of various metal elements, transition metals, such as Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, Cu and Cr, consistently exhibit relatively higher ORR performance. Among them, Fe and Co have been proven as the most active transition metal-ion centers for ORR catalysis [14]. Recently, Fe and Co elements were also introduced into ZIF structure to fabricate highly reactive catalysts for ORR in both acid and alkaline environments [15,16]. However, the thermodynamic instability of single atoms is a serious obstacle preventing further increases of the active site density and durability of PGM-free catalysts [17]. The instability of Fe2+ will further lead to the destruction of ZIF frameworks and agglomeration of metal atoms during the precursor synthesis [18] and pyrolysis [17,19] processes. To obtain a highly dispersed active site catalyst, it is necessary to have precise control of the size of the Fe nanoclusters [20]. Experimental results and simulations confirm that few-nanometer sized metal clusters can synergize with atomically dispersed Fe–N–C matrices, promoting the ORR process. On the other hand, the doping of dual metal elements, such as Co and Fe, can also improve the performance of catalysts by changing the electronic structure of active sites and decreasing the cleavage barrier of O–O during the ORR [2,21]. Therefore, active sites for ORR, constructed with alloy nanoclusters and single atoms, are anticipated to have elevated catalytic activity and electrochemical stability.

Besides the design of catalysts with high ORR active site density, the morphological structure of CLs is associated with mass transfer properties and is considered to be crucial to achieving high fuel cell performance. The RDE test is a conventional technique to investigate catalytic activity in the kinetic region (microscale) in a liquid environment. The thin-film catalyst layer and low concentration of dissolved oxygen limit experimental exploration and understanding of catalytic and mass-transfer influence on the cathode CL in the mixed diffusion–kinetic controlled region (<0.8 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE), where the maximum power density is usually obtained. For single cell tests (SCT, at the macroscale), the power density reflects the whole membrane electrode assembly (MEA) performance including cathode, membrane and anode, which hardly focus only on the cathode CL properties. Consequently, a novel half-cell test (HCT, mesoscale) was developed to study the sole contribution of the individual CL at operating conditions that are as close as possible to that of an actual fuel cell [22]. Since then, HCT has been adopted [23,24] to evaluate Pt-based or PGM-free-based CLs to eliminate the limitation of oxygen diffusion as well as the impacts of the membrane and anode [25]. For PGM-free catalysts with a high density of active sites, quasi-online tests (HCT) or online tests (SCT) are expected to identify the key factors in the relationship between cell performance and CL structure. In the present work, based on the careful design and preparation of highly reactive and stable Co/Fe-based alloy nanocluster catalysts, the multi-scale approaches of RDE, HCT and SCT were employed to reveal the features of catalyst, catalyst layer and MEA, respectively. This comprehensive investigation provides a more detailed structure-activity relationship of Co/Fe-based CLs, which can guide the design of high-performance PGM-free catalyst layers for anion-exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs) and proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs).

Carbon black (XC-72) was used as the substrate, similar to our previous work [26]. Co2+ and Fe2+ species were doped into the matrix of Zn-based ZIF, which served as the active sites for the ORR after pyrolytic conversion at 950 °C. In detail, 0.624 g zinc acetate (Aladdin Industrial Inc., China), 0.163 g cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Aladdin Industrial Inc., China) and 0.011 g anhydrous ferrous sulfate (Aladdin Industrial Inc., China) were dissolved in 40 mL methanol (Tianjin Yuanli Technology Co., Ltd., China) with 0.6 g polyvinylpyrrolidone (Aladdin Industrial Inc., China). After ultrasonic treatment for 5 min, followed by 30 min magnetic stirring, a uniform, transparent mixture was obtained. Then, 0.1 g XC-72 (Macklin Inc., China) was added into the above solution to absorb the metallic atoms, with an additional 5 min ultrasonic treatment and 20 min magnetic stirring. A 40 mL methanol containing 2.46 g 2-methylimidazole (Aladdin Industrial Inc., China) was rapidly added to the mixture in an ice-water bath under magnetic stirring (300 rpm) and stirring was continued for 40 min. Finally, the mixture was aged at room temperature for 72 h without stirring. The product, which is denoted as Zn0.85Co0.14Fe0.01-CB, was recovered using a centrifuge, followed by freeze-drying.

The precursor power was transferred into a tube furnace for pyrolysis under 200 mL min−1 Ar (Tianjin Dongxiang Co., Ltd., China) protection at 950 °C (heating rate is 5 °C min−1) for 2 h. After carbonization, the catalyst was cooled naturally to room temperature under continuous flow of Ar. No other post-treatment was done after pyrolysis of the precursor. The final catalyst derived from Co, Fe-doped ZIF-CB hybrid material is denoted as 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB.

To investigate the synergistic effect between metal alloy nanoclusters and single atoms, a control sample without Co element was synthesized (0.01Fe–CB). Compared with 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB, Co element was replaced by Zn during the synthesis of ZIF-CB precursor by same post-treatment process. The influence of Co and Fe ratio was also investigated by controlling the overall proportion of Co and Fe unchanged (15%) in ZIF precursor. The corresponding catalysts are denoted 0.15Co–CB (15% Co, 0% Fe), 0.10Co0.05Fe–CB (10% Co, 5% Fe) and 0.15Fe–CB (0% Co, 15% Fe), respectively. Beyond that, every synthetic step of these control samples is the same as 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB.

Field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) images were performed on a S-4800 FE-SEM (HITACHI). Field emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM) images were obtained on a JSM-2100F FE-TEM (JEOL) instrument, and the distribution of Co, Fe, C and N elements were obtained by an energy dispersive X-ray detector attached to FE-TEM. The scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) with the high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) method was used for chemical analysis. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted by a Q500 TGA (TA Instruments-Waters, LLC). 5 °C min−1 were employed under dry air (40 mL min−1). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of ZIF-CB precursor and catalyst were obtained on a diffractometer (D8-Focus) using Cu Kα radiation (k = 0.15418). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) patterns were recorded using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo ESCALAB 250XI) with an aluminum (mono) Kα source (1486.6 eV). The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra at the K-edge of Co and Fe for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB were collected at the BL07A1 beamline of National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC). The data were collected in fluorescence mode using a Lytle detector while the corresponding reference samples were collected in transmission mode. The samples were ground and uniformly daubed onto special adhesive tape. The obtained XAFS data were processed in Athena (version 0.9.26) for background, pre-edge line and post-edge line calibrations. Then, Fourier transform fitting was carried out in Artemis (version 0.9.26). The k3 weighting, k-range of 3–12 Å−1 and R range of 1 to ∼3 Å were used for the fitting of Fe, k-range of 3–12 Å−1 and R range of 1 to ∼2 Å were used for the fitting of Co. The four parameters, coordination number, bond length, Debye-Waller factor and E0 shift (CN, R, ΔE0) were fitted without fixing, the σ2 was set.

The density functional theory (DFT) calculation as implemented in the DMol3 code [27,28] was carried out for the spin-polarized calculations. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used as the exchange-correlation functional [29,30]. A double numerical basis set plus polarization function (DNP) and DFT semi-core pseudopotential (DSPP) were utilized for all the calculations. The k-point grid was 3 × 3 × 1 for all the calculations. A Fermi smearing method with a window size of 0.005 hartree was applied to the orbital occupancy to improve the computational performance. The convergence tolerances for the energy change, max force, and max displacement were 1 × 10−5 Ha, 0.002 Ha Å−1, and 0.005 Å, respectively. A 20 Å vacuum space was chosen to avoid the interaction from adjacent periodical images. The calculation method of free energy changes (ΔG) for each step was proposed by Nørskov et al. [31] as the following equation:
ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS + ΔG U + ΔG pH
where ΔE is obtained from DFT calculation, ΔZPE and ΔS refer to the zero-point energy and entropic energy of the adsorption molecule, respectively. ΔG U = −eU is the contribution of electrode potential. ΔG pH = 2.303 k B T pH, where k B is the Boltzmann constant and T is the application temperature (298.15 K).

The electrochemical measurements were carried out with an Autolab 302 N potentiostat/galvanostat with a standard three-electrode system. A graphite rod, an Ag/AgCl or saturated calomel electrode (in saturated KCl solution) and a glassy carbon RDE and RRDE (Pine Research Instrumentation) coated with catalysts film served as counter electrode, reference electrode and working electrode, respectively. The ink was prepared from 5 mg catalyst ultrasonically dispersed in 1 mL of a mixture of Nafion (5 wt%, 40 μL), isopropanol (730 μL) and ultrapure water (Milli-Q Advantage A10, 230 μL). 15 or 25 μL homogeneous ink was transferred to the surface of glassy carbon (0.196 cm2) and dried naturally for RDE and RRDE tests in alkaline and acid environments, respectively. The catalyst loading of CoFe-based catalyst is about 367 μg cm−2 for alkaline and 613 μg cm−2 for acid tests. Before linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), all electrodes were activated by cyclic voltammetry (CV, not exhibited in the paper) with a variational scan rate (100 mV s−1, 50 mV s−1 and 10 mV s−1). The rotational speed of the working electrode was fixed at 1600 rpm and the sweep rate was 5 mV s−1. For the RRDE test, the ring potential was maintained at 1.1 V vs RHE. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were conducted using the three-electrode system at different voltages with 5 mV amplitude from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.

A half-cell setup (manufactured by Tianjin Aida HengSheng Science & Technology Development Co., Ltd., China) was employed to mimic the fuel cell conditions to investigate the performance of gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs). The GDE was fabricated by spraying the catalyst ink (the recipe of catalyst ink is the same as the MEA) on the microporous layer side of the gas diffusion layer at 80 °C. The catalyst loading was fixed at 4 mg cm−2 for both acid and alkaline environments. Similar with previous research [23,25], the obtained GDE, placed between the flow channel and electrolyte (contacted with the CL side), served as the working electrode. The Ag/AgCl or saturated calomel electrodes (in saturated KCl solution) and carbon fiber, which respectively acted as reference electrode and counter electrode, were immersed into 0.1 M KOH or 0.1 M HClO4 to simulate the environment of AEMFC and PEMFC. Oxygen was introduced into the flow channel at 50 mL min−1 under 25 °C without backpressure or humidification. At first, a CV procedure was conducted from about 1.1 to 0.3 V vs RHE at 100 mV s−1 for 30 cycles to activate the GDE (not exhibited in the paper). After that, the sampled DC method was performed to obtain the polarization curve from 1.2 to 0 V vs RHE with each step being 50 mV for 0.5 s. The EIS method was also conducted in this system at different voltages with 5 mV amplitude from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Durability tests of different GDEs were obtained by a chronoamperometry method with half-cell setup at 0.8 V vs RHE for 10 h with a continuous oxygen supply (50 mL min−1, 25 °C) and atmospheric pressure.

For the AEMFC test, the GDE method was used to make both the anode and cathode catalyst layers (CLs), following procedures published in previous reports [32–34]. The PGM anode loading was 0.77 mgPtRu cm−2 while the PGM-free cathode was loaded to 1.28 mgcat cm−2. Both GDEs, along with a 9 cm2 piece of radiation-grafted poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene)-based AEM (Prof. Varcoe, Surrey University, UK) [35–37], containing covalently-bonded benzyltrimethylammonium (BTMA) head-groups (ion-exchange capacity of 2.11 ± 0.11 mmol g−1 and 50 μm hydrated membrane thickness), were separately immersed in petri dishes of 1 M KOH aqueous solution for 1 h. The 1 M KOH solution was changed every 20 min, to ensure full conversion of the AEM into its hydroxide form. The AEMFC was assembled between pairs of 5 cm2 single-serpentine graphite bipolar flow fields with PTFE gaskets, in order to arrive at a compression of 21% and torqued to 4.5 N m. The cell was tested in an 850e Scribner Associates Fuel Cell test station under optimized relative humidity with H2-O2 flowing to the anode and cathode, respectively, at 1000 sccm. The tests were performed at 60 °C, first at atmospheric pressure followed by 100 kPa of applied backpressure.

For the PEMFC test, the 0.14Co0.01Fe–N–C catalysts were ultrasonically dispersed in a mixture of Nafion ionomer (5 wt%) and isopropanol/water (3:1 v/v) to obtain the cathode ink. To reduce the contact resistance of catalyst layer and membrane, the ink was sprayed onto one side of a clean Nafion 212 proton exchange membrane (catalyst coating membrane method, CCM) at 80 °C, with an active area of 4 cm2. A piece (2 × 2 cm2) of commercial Pt/C GDE (Hesen, China) was employed as the anode electrode. The cathode catalyst loading (4 mg cm−2) was about six times larger than that of the anode (0.4 mgPt cm−2, 0.67 mgPt/C cm−2). The prepared membrane coated catalyst was dried at 60 °C for 3 h. After that, it was assembled with GDL by hot-pressing at 130 °C under 500 psi for 2 min to obtain the MEA. Then the MEA was evaluated using Greenlight G60, applying a torque of 6 N m on the single cell. Constant gas flow of H2 (400 sccm) and O2 (800 sccm) was applied to the anode and cathode, respectively, with 100% relative humidity at 80 °C with 0 and 100 kPa backpressure. The durability tests of both AEMFC and PEMFC were performed by a galvanostatic method at 100 mA cm−2 for 10 h. The gas flow rate and back pressure of the durability tests are consistent with polarization curve tests.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Influence of Co and Fe ratio
ce:section.ce:para: To obtain a high performance ZIF-derived catalyst, Fe element, which is widely recognized as possessing highly active sites, was doped into a Co, Zn-ZIF framework. Firstly, the stability of Co, Fe-based ZIF precursor was investigated by adjusting the atomic ratio of Co to Fe, as shown in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns in Fig. 1 . The ratio of Zn element is fixed at 85% during the precursor synthesis for all the catalysts. As the percentage of Fe ions increases from 1% (0.04 mM) for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB to 15% (0.60 mM) for 0.15Fe–CB, there is an obvious damping of XRD intensity. The above result may indicate that a large amount Fe2+ is not beneficial to the formation of ZIF framework due to its poor chemical stability (Fe2+ is readily oxidized to Fe3+ in methanol, which is used in the preparation of ZIF). The atomic ratio is a simple and effective control to inhibit the destruction of the ZIF framework and achieve a high dispersion of Co/Fe atoms without the requirement of inert atmosphere, as reported in previous studies [18]. The properties of the precursor further influence the structure of the final catalyst. After pyrolysis, Co nanoclusters form for 0.15Co–CB, as observed in XRD (Fig. S1) and discussed in our previous research [26]. When a small quantity of Fe element was introduced into the precursor, Co nanoclusters (0.15Co–CB) were transformed to Co0.72Fe0.28 nanoclusters [38] (JCPDS No. 51-0740) for the 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB catalyst (Fig. 1b2). A slow-scan XRD test was carried out to further detect the impurities of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB from 40 to 50° with 0.005° s−1. As shown in Fig. S2, compared with 0.15Co–CB and 0.15Fe–CB, only one diffraction peak at 43.87° can be detected for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB, attributed to the (330) crystal plane of Co0.72Fe0.28. The above result further confirms the relatively high purity of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB catalyst. With increasing Fe content, the chemical composition of the catalyst evolves and forms Co3Fe7 and Fe3C for 0.10Co0.05Fe–CB and 0.15Fe–CB, respectively.

To illustrate the different metal contents of Co/Fe dual-doped and Fe single-doped ZIF catalysts, 0.01Fe–CB was synthesized as a control sample. No metal nanoparticle signal is observed in the XRD pattern for 0.01Fe–CB, as shown in Fig. S1, indicating completely atomically-dispersed Fe element without nanocluster formation. Scanning transmission electron microscopy images taken with a high-angle annular dark field detector (STEM-HAADF) of catalyst borders were analyzed to qualitatively compare the active site densities of the catalysts with and without nanoclusters. The bright region of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB (Fig. 2 b), representing the distribution of metal atoms, is more obvious than that of 0.01Fe–CB (Fig. 2d), indicting a higher density of active metals in the dual-metal doped catalyst. This observation is also confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in Fig. S3, the residual mass percentage increases from about 0% for 0.01Fe–CB to 6.5% for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB, after pyrolysis in air at 900 °C. The image at higher magnification using HR-TEM further confirms the presence of metal nanoclusters (the black dots in Fig. 2g) in 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB. However, few nanoclusters do not influence the overall homogeneous dispersion of metal and nitrogen elements, as shown in TEM-mapping (Fig. 2h) of Co, Fe and N elements.

A larger proportion of pyridinic–N [39] and M–N [40] species, which are considered as the catalyst active sites [41], can be observed in 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Fig. S4). The peaks at 398.4, 399.1, 400.2, 401.1 and 402.6 eV correspond to pyridinic-N, M‒N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N species, respectively [42,43]. Corresponding with an increase in the percentage of Fe, more N occurs as graphitic-N, leading to the decrease of M‒N percentage. For Fe element, the signals of Fe0, Fe2+, and Fe3+ are detected at around 706.9, 707.9 and 711.3 eV, respectively [44,45]. It is worth mentioning that the intensity of the Fe signal increases significantly with the emerging Fe0 signal at 706.9 eV, when more Fe element was introduced, as shown in Fig. S5. An optimized Co and Fe ratio can reduce the oxidation of Fe2+ in the precursor to achieve a catalyst with the lowest oxygen element concentration (Fig. S6). Normally, high temperature pyrolysis is considered as the main reason for metal atom agglomeration, which disadvantageously destroys the active Fe–N structure. However, in the present work, more evidence indicates that the unstable chemical properties of Fe also lead to serious agglomeration before pyrolysis (during precursor synthesis), which can be alleviated by alloying to obtain more stable PGM-free catalysts. Here, we show that the introduction of Co and Fe dual metals in the ZIF precursor facilitates the dispersion of Fe element, which is anticipated to increase the density of the ORR site [46].

To show the structure more clearly, additional evidence is provided by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), including X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). As shown in Fig. S7a and c, the Co and Fe absorption edges of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB both shifted toward lower energy with respect to cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) and iron phthalocyanine (FePc), indicating the coexistence of metal nanoparticles and positively charged metal single atoms [20]. The Fourier transform (FT) EXAFS spectra (Fig. 3 a and b) for both Fe and Co K-edge of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB show two peaks located at ∼1.5 and 2.2 Å, corresponding to the M–N (O) and M–M (M = Co or Fe) scattering paths, respectively. No Fe–Fe or Co–Co bonds at ∼2.5 Å were detected. Argon was used to prevent the sample from oxidizing, during pyrolysis process. Therefore, the scattering path at 1.5 Å in R-space can be assigned to Fe–N or Co–N scattering path. Furthermore, the fitting cures and parameters of EXAFS are shown in Fig. S7 and Table S1. The fitting result indicates that more Fe atoms are coordinated with N atoms and form Fe–N4, compared with Co atoms. Combining the XAS, XPS and XRD analysis, the coexistence of M-N4 (M = Co and Fe) and CoFe nanoalloy is unambiguously confirmed.

Based on the physical and chemical characterization of obtained catalyst, density functional theory (DFT) calculations of single atom catalyst (SAC) with or without CoFe nanoalloy were performed using the computational hydrogen electrode model. As shown in Fig. 3c, four models were constructed, including Co- or Fe-based single atom catalysts (denoted as SAC-CoN4 and SAC-FeN4) and single atom catalysts combined with metallic CoFe alloy (denoted as CoFe-CoN4 and CoFe-FeN4). As shown in Fig. S8, compared with SAC-CoN4 and SAC-FeN4, the d-band center of CoFe-CoN4 and CoFe-FeN4 increase from −3.03 eV for SAC-CoN4 to −2.54 eV for CoFe-CoN4; from −2.39 eV for SAC-FeN4 to −1.65 eV for CoFe-FeN4. The lower d-band, which can decrease the adsorption energy of O2, leads to better catalytic performance [47]. Furthermore, the Gibbs free energy of each ORR step was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 3d and e. Due to the synergistic effect of CoFe alloy, the overpotentials of M-N4 (M = Co or Fe) active sites in CoFe–CoN4 (0.25 eV) and CoFe–FeN4 (0.34 eV) decrease obviously, indicating a significant improvement in the ORR catalytic performance.

To verify practical performance of the obtained catalysts, the Co/Fe–N–C with highly dispersed CoFe nanoalloy was comprehensively investigated using multi-scale experimental methods (RDE, HCT, and SCT) in different current density ranges to reveal the relationship between the intrinsic activity and corresponding CL performance. As shown in Fig. 4 a, 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB catalyst with CoFe nanoalloy particles shows a higher half-wave potential at around 0.86 V vs RHE in 0.1 M KOH than 20 wt.% Pt/C (Johnson Matthey) catalyst (0.81 V vs RHE), which is also comparable to state-of-the-art 60 wt.% Pt/C (Johnson Matthey). In acid environment, the half-wave potential achieves 0.76 V vs RHE for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB with a very small fraction of Fe doping, which is also comparable to that of Pt/C catalysts (Johnson Matthey), and better than most PGM-free catalysts reported in the literature (Table S2). A high electron transfer number and low H2O2 yield in alkaline and acid environments imply good bifunctional activity of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB according to RRDE analysis (as shown in Fig. S9). To further investigate the reason for good performance, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis in the kinetic region (0.85 V vs RHE) was carried out. The double layer capacitance (C dl) values, reflecting the electrochemical active surface area, can be extracted from the EIS data in alkali (Fig. S10a) and acid (Fig. S10b), as summarized in Fig. S10c. Compared with other catalysts, 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB has the largest C dl, indicating the larger electrochemical surface area for the ORR process. It should be noted that the C dl values increase from 7.07 and 4.97 F g−1 for 0.01Fe–CB to 14.56 and 6.36 F g−1 for 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB in 0.1 M HClO4 and KOH, respectively, indicating that the CoFe nanoalloy has a larger electrochemical surface area than single atom catalyst (0.01Fe–CB), consistent with STEM-HAADF analysis. The above ORR performance result further confirms the better catalytic activity of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB, due to the synergistic effect of M‒N4 and nanoalloy particle, which is consistent with the DFT calculation results.

To evaluate the performance of 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB derived catalyst layer, the catalyst ink was sprayed onto a gas diffusion layer (GDL, denoted as Co/Fe–CL, 4 mgcat cm−2) and tested in a half-cell setup. For comparison, a Pt–CL (0.4 mgPt cm−2) was fabricated by the same method using commercial 60 wt.% Pt/C (Johnson Matthey), which is most commonly used as the catalyst layer material for commercial fuel cell setups. Fig. 4b shows that the onset potential of both Pt–CL and Co/Fe–CL are almost same. However, with a decrease of potential, Co/Fe–CL exhibits larger current density, compared with Pt–CL, which may be due to the high catalyst loading of Co/Fe–CL with a greater number of active sites. Compared with the performance in alkaline environment, the catalytic activity of Co/Fe–CL in acid is relatively lower, which is consistent with the results obtained in the RDE tests. However, compared with RDE, a much larger current density (> 100 mA cm−2) can be obtained due to effective oxygen diffusion through the GDL. The stability tests of both the Pt and Co/Fe‒CLs are investigated at 0.7 V vs RHE (before iR correction) by analyzing current density change with time as the function, shown in Fig. S11a. Compared with the Pt–CL, the Co/Fe–CL shows higher stability in both acid (80.1% conservation rate) and alkaline (90.8% conservation rate) environments after 10 h of chronoamperometry tests, indicating the good stability of Co/Fe–CL.

Subsequently, the 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB was used to make a MEA (denoted as Co/Fe-MEA), which was measured in a single cell to investigate the fuel cell performance, as shown in Fig. 4c. The open cell voltage of Co/Fe-MEA was 0.99 V and 0.88 V in AEMFC and PEMFC, respectively, which is consistent with the open-circuit potential obtained by the RDE and HCT methods. For the AEMFC, as shown in Fig. 4c1, the peak power density increases from 222 mW cm−2 under 0 kPa to 304 mW cm−2 under 100 kPa back-pressure of both H2 and O2. The PEMFC also exhibits a relatively high peak power density of 465 mW cm−2 under 100 kPa of both H2 and O2 at 80 °C (Fig. 4c2), indicating the universality of this catalyst in different fuel cells. The in-operando durability of both AEMFC and PEMFC was also investigated by a single cell setup using a galvanostatic method. As shown in Fig. S11b, after a 10 h stability test under 100 mA cm−2, the cell voltage of the PEMFC decreased to 83.9% of its initial value, which is consistent with the HCT stability test (80.1%), indicating the good stability and practicability of CoFe nanoalloy catalyst for PEMFC application. However, the cell voltage of the AEMFC decreased dramatically from 0.65 V to 0.38 V (a decrease to 58.5%), which has a big difference from HCT data (90.8%). This result implies that there may be a non-negligible influence of anode [48] and/or the membrane [49] during the single cell test, especially in AEMFC, which further emphasizes the importance of multi-scale methods encompassing RDE, HCT and SCT to obtain more accurate and overall information for fuel cell CL design.

Due to the fine compositional adjustment of ZIF precursors, a highly dispersed dual-metal catalyst was obtained after pyrolysis at 950 °C. Compared with previous research, the catalyst forms highly dispersed, highly-active CoFe sites without the requirement of an inert atmosphere during the precursor synthesis. Physicochemical characterization and DFT calculations proved the presence of high-density metal active sites with a synergistic effect of CoFe alloy nanoparticles and M–N4 (M = Co or Fe). To investigate its possible application in polymer electrolyte fuel cells, multi-scale evaluation was adopted with the aim of more clearly understanding the factors contributing to efficient CLs. Due to the diffusion limitations of dissolved oxygen in aqueous solution, the RDE method mainly focused on the kinetic regions (at around 0.8–0.9 V vs RHE) for few-micron thick catalyst layers (Fig. 5 a and d). As discussed in Fig. 4a, the Co/Fe-based catalyst exhibited good performance in the kinetic region for both acid and alkaline environments. In order to obtain a useful catalyst layer for fuel cell application, a thicker CL (about 40 μm, with a 13 μm microporous layer in the lower level) with a high porosity is usually required (Fig. 5b and e) to create a sufficiently electrochemically active surface area (Fig. 5g). HCT is a powerful tool to evaluate the CL performance on a GDE at lower potential region (at about 0.6–0.8 V vs RHE) by excluding the influence of oxygen diffusion limitation. As shown in Fig. 4b1 and b2, a higher current density (>100 mA cm−2) can be obtained in the HCT compared with that in the RDE. When applying Co/Fe–CLs in the AEMFC and PEMFC (Fig. 5c and f), similar CL thickness and microstructure can be observed via SEM and digital microscope (Fig. S13) analyses, compared with HCT. It is worth mentioning that, the potentials of HCT and SCT at the same current density (100 mA cm−2) are similar (Fig. 5h), indicating the practicability of the HCT method for ORR research. The above results integrally introduced the good performance of CoFe nanoalloy catalyst, from material design and simulation analysis to fuel cell application. This work not only provides a synthetic method for high performance ORR catalyst, but also highlights the multi-scale strategy for fast and accurate evaluation of fuel cell catalyst and catalyst layer.

Based on multi-scale analyses, a greater comprehensive understanding of ORR catalyst design for fuel cell applications is gained. A 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB ORR catalyst with high active site density is obtained after pyrolysis, by convenient introduction of Co and Fe elements into a ZIF-8 framework precursor. In addition to the conventional RDE tests, more relevant and accurate performance data can be obtained by a HCT test using practical catalyst loadings and efficient oxygen transport. Especially in the fuel cell working ranges (0.6–0.8 V), the HCT exhibits a much larger current density (more than 100 mA cm−2), compared with previous ORR catalyst tests. The 0.14Co0.01Fe–CB derived PGM-free CL exhibits comparable catalytic performance to the best available precious metal catalyst (60 wt.% Pt/C, Johnson Matthey) with better stability in both acid and alkaline environments. This work may guide the design and evaluation procedure for fuel cell cathode catalysts, due to the more comprehensive understanding of catalytic activity and stability of the CL.
